title: Introduction to JavaScript
description: Test your knowledge of JavaScript basics

questions.question: Which keyword is used to declare a variable in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, 'var' is one of the keywords used to declare variables, along with 'let' and 'const'.

questions.question: What will '2' + 2 evaluate to in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: JavaScript performs type coercion and treats the + operator as string concatenation when one operand is a string.

questions.question: Which built-in method is used to convert a string to lowercase?
questions.explanation: The toLowerCase() method returns the calling string value converted to lowercase.

questions.question: How do you create a function in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Functions in JavaScript are defined using the 'function' keyword followed by a name and parentheses.

questions.question: Which operator is used for strict equality comparison?
questions.explanation: The === operator checks for strict equality, comparing both value and type without performing type conversion.

title: World Geography
description: Test your knowledge of world geography

questions.question: Which is the largest ocean on Earth?
questions.explanation: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth, covering more than 30% of the Earth's surface.

questions.question: Which country is known as the Land of the Rising Sun?
questions.explanation: Japan is known as the Land of the Rising Sun because from China, Japan appears to be in the direction where the Sun rises.

questions.question: Which is the longest river in the world?
questions.explanation: The Nile River is the longest river in the world, stretching about 6,650 kilometers.

questions.question: Which desert is the largest in the world?
questions.explanation: The Antarctic Desert is the largest desert in the world, covering the entire continent of Antarctica.

questions.question: Which is the smallest country in the world by land area?
questions.explanation: Vatican City is the smallest country in the world, with a total area of approximately 0.44 square kilometers.

title: Famous Scientists
description: Test your knowledge about famous scientists throughout history

questions.question: Who developed the theory of relativity?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein developed the theory of relativity, which fundamentally changed our understanding of space, time, and gravity.

questions.question: Who is known for the discovery of penicillin?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928, which became the first widely used antibiotic.

questions.question: Who proposed the heliocentric model of the solar system?
questions.explanation: Nicolaus Copernicus proposed the heliocentric model, placing the Sun at the center of the solar system rather than Earth.

questions.question: Who discovered the structure of DNA?
questions.explanation: James Watson and Francis Crick, with crucial data from Rosalind Franklin, determined the double helix structure of DNA in 1953.

questions.question: Who developed the periodic table of elements?
questions.explanation: Dmitri Mendeleev created the first widely recognized periodic table in 1869, organizing elements by atomic weight and chemical properties.

title: Ancient History
description: Test your knowledge of ancient civilizations and history

questions.question: Which ancient civilization built the Machu Picchu?
questions.explanation: Machu Picchu was built by the Incas in the 15th century and is located in present-day Peru.

questions.question: Who was the first Emperor of unified China?
questions.explanation: Qin Shi Huang (259 BC ‚Äì 210 BC) unified China in 221 BC and became the first emperor of the Qin dynasty.

questions.question: Which ancient wonder was located in Alexandria?
questions.explanation: The Lighthouse of Alexandria (Pharos) was one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, built in the 3rd century BC.

questions.question: Who wrote 'The Republic'?
questions.explanation: The Republic was written by the Greek philosopher Plato around 375 BC, and explores justice, government, and society.

questions.question: Which empire was ruled by Hammurabi and his famous code of laws?
questions.explanation: Hammurabi was the sixth king of the First Babylonian dynasty, ruling from around 1792 to 1750 BC.

title: Music Theory Basics
description: Test your knowledge of fundamental music theory concepts

questions.question: How many lines are in a standard musical staff?
questions.explanation: A standard musical staff consists of five horizontal lines and four spaces, each representing a different musical pitch.

questions.question: What does the Italian term 'forte' mean in musical notation?
questions.explanation: Forte (f) is a dynamic marking indicating that the music should be played loudly.

questions.question: Which of these is not one of the three basic elements of music?
questions.explanation: Rhythm, melody, and harmony are considered the three basic elements of music. Frequency is a physics term related to pitch.

questions.question: How many semitones make up an octave?
questions.explanation: An octave consists of 12 semitones (half steps) in Western music theory.

questions.question: Which clef is typically used for lower-pitched instruments?
questions.explanation: The bass clef is used for lower-pitched instruments like bass guitar, cello, trombone, and the left hand in piano music.

title: Film Directors and Their Works
description: Test your knowledge about famous film directors and their notable works

questions.question: Who directed 'Pulp Fiction'?
questions.explanation: Pulp Fiction (1994) was directed by Quentin Tarantino and is considered one of his masterpieces.

questions.question: Which director is known for the 'Three Colors' trilogy?
questions.explanation: The Three Colors trilogy (Blue, White, Red) was directed by Polish filmmaker Krzysztof Kie≈õlowski in the early 1990s.

questions.question: Who directed 'The Godfather'?
questions.explanation: The Godfather (1972) was directed by Francis Ford Coppola and is widely regarded as one of the greatest films ever made.

questions.question: Which filmmaker directed 'Seven Samurai'?
questions.explanation: Seven Samurai (1954) was directed by Akira Kurosawa and is considered one of the most influential films in cinema history.

questions.question: Who directed '2001: A Space Odyssey'?
questions.explanation: 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) was directed by Stanley Kubrick and is renowned for its groundbreaking visual effects and philosophical themes.

title: World Cuisines
description: Test your knowledge about foods and culinary traditions from around the world

questions.question: Which country is the origin of sushi?
questions.explanation: Sushi originated in Japan, where it has been prepared since the 8th century.

questions.question: Which cuisine is known for dishes like paella and gazpacho?
questions.explanation: Paella (a rice dish) and gazpacho (cold soup) are traditional Spanish dishes.

questions.question: Which country is the birthplace of the kebab?
questions.explanation: The kebab originated in Turkey, though variations exist throughout the Middle East and Mediterranean.

questions.question: What is the main ingredient in traditional Italian risotto?
questions.explanation: Risotto is a northern Italian rice dish made with Arborio rice, a short-grain rice that becomes creamy when cooked.

questions.question: Which country is known for inventing the croissant?
questions.explanation: Though associated with France, the croissant was actually invented in Austria as the 'kipferl' before being introduced to France.

title: Introduction to Python
description: Test your knowledge of Python programming basics

questions.question: What symbol is used for comments in Python?
questions.explanation: In Python, the hashtag (#) symbol is used to start a comment line.

questions.question: Which of these is not a Python data type?
questions.explanation: While arrays exist in Python through the NumPy library, they are not a built-in data type. Lists are Python's native sequence type.

questions.question: What does the len() function do in Python?
options: Returns the largest item in an iterable
Returns the length of an object
Checks if all items in an iterable are True
Returns the smallest item in an iterable
questions.correctAnswer: Returns the length of an object
questions.explanation: The len() function returns the number of items in an object like a string, list, or tuple.

questions.question: How do you create a function in Python?
questions.explanation: Functions in Python are defined using the 'def' keyword followed by the function name and parentheses.

questions.question: Which operator is used for exponentiation in Python?
questions.explanation: The double asterisk (**) is used for exponentiation in Python. For example, 2**3 equals 8.

title: Marine Biology
description: Test your knowledge about ocean life and marine ecosystems

questions.question: What is the largest animal on Earth?
questions.explanation: The Blue Whale is the largest animal known to have ever existed, reaching lengths of up to 30 meters and weights up to 173 tons.

questions.question: Which ocean zone receives enough sunlight for photosynthesis?
questions.explanation: The euphotic zone, also known as the sunlight zone, is the upper layer of the ocean that receives enough sunlight for photosynthesis to occur.

questions.question: What do marine biologists call a group of jellyfish?
questions.explanation: A group of jellyfish is called a bloom, swarm, or smack, with 'bloom' being the most scientifically used term.

questions.question: Which of these is not a type of marine mammal?
questions.explanation: Sharks are fish, not mammals. They have gills instead of lungs and lay eggs rather than giving birth to live young (with some exceptions).

questions.question: What percentage of Earth's oxygen is produced by phytoplankton in the oceans?
questions.explanation: Marine phytoplankton produce approximately 50% of the world's oxygen through photosynthesis.

title: Sports History
description: Test your knowledge about the history of various sports and athletic achievements

questions.question: In which year were the first modern Olympic Games held?
questions.explanation: The first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens, Greece, in 1896.

questions.question: Which country won the first FIFA World Cup in 1930?
questions.explanation: Uruguay won the inaugural FIFA World Cup in 1930, defeating Argentina 4-2 in the final.

questions.question: Who is the only boxer to finish his career as an undefeated world heavyweight champion?
questions.explanation: Rocky Marciano retired in 1956 with a perfect record of 49-0, the only heavyweight champion to finish his career undefeated.

questions.question: Which tennis player has won the most Grand Slam singles titles?
questions.explanation: As of 2023, Novak Djokovic holds the record for most Grand Slam singles titles in men's tennis with 24 titles.

questions.question: In which year did women first compete in the modern Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Women first competed in the 1900 Olympic Games in Paris, participating in tennis, sailing, croquet, equestrian, and golf.

title: Advanced Calculus
description: Test your knowledge of advanced calculus concepts

questions.question: What is the derivative of e^x?
questions.explanation: The function e^x is its own derivative, making it unique among elementary functions.

questions.question: Which theorem states that if f has a local extremum at c, and f is differentiable at c, then f'(c) = 0?
questions.explanation: Fermat's Theorem (or Fermat's stationary point theorem) states that if f has a local extremum at c, and f is differentiable at c, then f'(c) = 0.

questions.question: What is the integral of 1/x?
questions.explanation: The integral of 1/x is ln|x| + C, where C is the constant of integration. The absolute value ensures it works for negative x values.

questions.question: What is the Taylor series expansion of sin(x) around x = 0?
questions.explanation: The Taylor series for sin(x) at x = 0 is x - x^3/3! + x^5/5! - ... or more formally, sum from n=0 to infinity of (-1)^n * x^(2n+1) / (2n+1)!

questions.question: Which of the following is the definition of the Riemann integral?
options: The limit of a sum of products
The rate of change of a function
questions.correctAnswer: The limit of a sum of products
questions.explanation: The Riemann integral is defined as the limit of a sum of products of the form f(x_i) * delta_x as the partition becomes finer (max delta_x approaches 0).

title: Literature Classics
description: Test your knowledge of classic literature and famous authors

questions.question: Who wrote '1984'?
questions.explanation: '1984' was written by George Orwell and published in 1949, depicting a dystopian future society.

questions.question: Which Shakespeare play features the character Ophelia?
questions.explanation: Ophelia is a character in Shakespeare's 'Hamlet', where she is Polonius's daughter and Hamlet's love interest.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Pride and Prejudice'?
questions.explanation: 'Pride and Prejudice' was written by Jane Austen and published in 1813.

questions.question: What is the name of the main character in 'The Catcher in the Rye'?
questions.explanation: Holden Caulfield is the teenage protagonist and narrator of J.D. Salinger's 'The Catcher in the Rye'.

questions.question: Which novel begins with the line 'Call me Ishmael'?
options: The Old Man and the Sea
questions.explanation: 'Moby Dick' by Herman Melville begins with this famous opening line.

title: Computer Networks
description: Test your knowledge of computer networking concepts

questions.question: Which protocol is used for secure web browsing?
questions.explanation: HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure) is used for secure communication over computer networks.

questions.question: What is the purpose of DNS?
options: To convert domain names to IP addresses
questions.correctAnswer: To convert domain names to IP addresses
questions.explanation: DNS (Domain Name System) translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses.

questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model handles routing?
questions.explanation: The Network Layer (Layer 3) of the OSI model handles routing between different networks.

questions.question: What is the default port number for HTTP?
questions.explanation: Port 80 is the default port for HTTP traffic on the web.

questions.question: Which of these is not a valid IP address?
questions.explanation: IP address octets cannot exceed 255, making 256.1.2.3 invalid.

title: Human Biology
description: Test your knowledge of human anatomy and physiology

questions.question: Which organ is responsible for producing insulin?
questions.explanation: The pancreas produces insulin in its beta cells, which regulates blood sugar levels.

questions.question: How many chambers are there in the human heart?
questions.explanation: The human heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles.

questions.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?
questions.explanation: The skin is the largest organ in the human body, covering about 20 square feet in adults.

questions.question: Which blood type is known as the universal donor?
questions.explanation: O negative blood can be given to patients of all blood types, making it the universal donor.

questions.question: How many pairs of chromosomes do humans normally have?
questions.explanation: Humans typically have 23 pairs of chromosomes, for a total of 46 chromosomes.

title: World Languages
description: Test your knowledge of languages and linguistics

questions.question: Which is the most spoken language in the world by native speakers?
questions.explanation: Mandarin Chinese has the most native speakers, with over 900 million people.

questions.question: Which language family does Japanese belong to?
questions.explanation: Japanese belongs to the Japonic language family, which includes Japanese and the Ryukyuan languages.

questions.question: What is the official language of Brazil?
questions.explanation: Portuguese is the official language of Brazil, brought by Portuguese colonizers.

questions.question: Which alphabet has 14 basic vowels?
questions.explanation: The Korean alphabet (Hangul) has 14 basic vowels and 10 basic consonants.

questions.question: What is the term for a word that sounds the same as another but has different meaning and spelling?
questions.explanation: Homophones are words that sound alike but have different meanings and spellings (e.g., 'there' and 'their').

title: Economics Fundamentals
description: Test your knowledge of basic economic concepts

questions.question: What is the law of supply and demand?
options: Prices rise when supply exceeds demand
Prices fall when demand exceeds supply
Prices adjust to balance supply and demand
Prices remain constant regardless of supply and demand
questions.correctAnswer: Prices adjust to balance supply and demand
questions.explanation: The law of supply and demand states that prices will adjust to bring supply and demand into balance in a market economy.

questions.question: What is GDP?
questions.explanation: GDP measures the total monetary value of all finished goods and services produced within a country's borders in a specific time period.

questions.question: What is inflation?
questions.explanation: Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising over time.

questions.question: What is a monopoly?
questions.explanation: A monopoly exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular good or service.

questions.question: What is opportunity cost?
options: The monetary cost of an opportunity
The cost of starting a business
The value of the next best alternative foregone
The cost of labor in production
questions.correctAnswer: The value of the next best alternative foregone
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative that must be given up when making a choice.

title: Psychology Basics
description: Test your knowledge of psychological concepts and theories

questions.question: Who is considered the father of psychoanalysis?
questions.explanation: Sigmund Freud developed psychoanalysis and influenced many aspects of modern psychology.

questions.question: What is classical conditioning?
questions.explanation: Classical conditioning is a learning process where a neutral stimulus becomes associated with a meaningful stimulus.

questions.question: Which part of the brain is primarily responsible for memory?
questions.explanation: The hippocampus plays a major role in learning and memory, particularly the formation of new memories.

questions.question: What is cognitive dissonance?
options: Mental conflict between beliefs and actions
questions.correctAnswer: Mental conflict between beliefs and actions
questions.explanation: Cognitive dissonance is the mental discomfort that results from holding contradictory beliefs or ideas.

questions.question: What is the Hawthorne Effect?
options: Changes in behavior when being observed
questions.correctAnswer: Changes in behavior when being observed
questions.explanation: The Hawthorne Effect describes how people modify their behavior when they know they're being observed.

title: Environmental Science
description: Test your knowledge of environmental systems and conservation

questions.question: What is the greenhouse effect?
options: Trapping of heat by atmospheric gases
Effect of green light on plants
questions.correctAnswer: Trapping of heat by atmospheric gases
questions.explanation: The greenhouse effect is the warming of Earth's surface due to atmospheric gases trapping heat from the sun.

questions.question: Which gas is responsible for the largest percentage of the greenhouse effect?
questions.explanation: Water vapor accounts for about 60-70% of the natural greenhouse effect, though CO2 is the main human-influenced greenhouse gas.

questions.question: What is biodiversity?
options: Variety of life in an ecosystem
questions.correctAnswer: Variety of life in an ecosystem
questions.explanation: Biodiversity refers to the variety of living species within a given area, including plants, animals, and microorganisms.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of ocean acidification?
questions.explanation: Ocean acidification occurs when seawater absorbs carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, making the water more acidic.

questions.question: What is an ecosystem service?
questions.explanation: Ecosystem services are the direct and indirect benefits that people obtain from natural ecosystems.

title: Architecture Through History
description: Test your knowledge of architectural styles and famous buildings

questions.question: Which architectural style is characterized by pointed arches and flying buttresses?
questions.explanation: Gothic architecture, popular in medieval Europe, is known for its pointed arches, flying buttresses, and tall spires.

questions.question: Who designed the Falling Water house?
questions.explanation: Fallingwater was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in 1935 and is famous for its integration with the natural waterfall.

questions.question: Which ancient civilization built the Parthenon?
questions.explanation: The Parthenon was built in the 5th century BCE by the ancient Greeks as a temple to Athena.

questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of Brutalist architecture?
questions.explanation: Brutalist architecture is characterized by the use of exposed, raw concrete and bold geometric shapes.

questions.question: Who designed the Sydney Opera House?
questions.explanation: The Sydney Opera House was designed by Danish architect J√∏rn Utzon and completed in 1973.

title: Philosophy 101
description: Test your knowledge of philosophical concepts and thinkers

questions.question: Who wrote 'Meditations on First Philosophy'?
questions.explanation: Ren√© Descartes wrote 'Meditations on First Philosophy' in 1641, introducing his famous 'I think, therefore I am'.

questions.question: What is epistemology?
questions.explanation: Epistemology is the branch of philosophy concerned with the theory of knowledge.

questions.question: Which philosopher wrote 'The Republic'?
questions.explanation: Plato wrote 'The Republic', which discusses justice, the nature of the just state, and the just man.

questions.question: What is existentialism primarily concerned with?
questions.explanation: Existentialism focuses on the human condition and emphasizes individual existence, freedom, and choice.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra'?
questions.explanation: 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra' was written by Friedrich Nietzsche and introduces the concept of the √úbermensch.

title: Space Exploration
description: Test your knowledge of space missions and astronomical discoveries

questions.question: Who was the first human to walk on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong was the first person to walk on the Moon during the Apollo 11 mission in 1969.

questions.question: Which space probe has traveled the farthest from Earth?
questions.explanation: Voyager 1, launched in 1977, is the farthest human-made object from Earth, having entered interstellar space.

questions.question: What was the first artificial satellite to orbit Earth?
questions.explanation: Sputnik 1, launched by the Soviet Union in 1957, was the first artificial satellite to orbit Earth.

questions.question: Which planet has the most moons in our solar system?
questions.explanation: Jupiter has the most moons, with over 80 confirmed natural satellites.

questions.question: What is the name of SpaceX's first reusable rocket?
questions.explanation: The Falcon 9 was SpaceX's first reusable rocket, revolutionizing space launch technology.

title: World Religions
description: Test your knowledge of major world religions and their practices

questions.question: What are the Five Pillars of Islam?
options: Prayer, Charity, Fasting, Pilgrimage, Declaration of Faith
Baptism, Communion, Confirmation, Marriage, Last Rites
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer, Charity, Fasting, Pilgrimage, Declaration of Faith
questions.explanation: The Five Pillars of Islam are Shahada (Declaration of Faith), Salah (Prayer), Zakat (Charity), Sawm (Fasting), and Hajj (Pilgrimage).

questions.question: Which religion believes in reincarnation?
questions.explanation: Hinduism believes in the cycle of rebirth (samsara) and reincarnation based on karma.

questions.question: Who is considered the founder of Buddhism?
questions.explanation: Siddhartha Gautama, known as the Buddha, founded Buddhism in ancient India.

questions.question: What is the holy book of Judaism?
questions.explanation: The Torah is the central and most important text of Judaism.

questions.question: Which day is the Christian Sabbath?
questions.explanation: Most Christians observe Sunday as their Sabbath, though some denominations observe Saturday.

title: Physical Fitness
description: Test your knowledge of exercise science and fitness principles

questions.question: What is the recommended minimum amount of weekly cardiovascular exercise for adults?
questions.explanation: The WHO recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity throughout the week for adults.

questions.question: Which type of muscle fiber is primarily used in endurance activities?
questions.explanation: Type I (slow-twitch) muscle fibers are resistant to fatigue and used primarily in endurance activities.

questions.question: What is HIIT?
questions.explanation: HIIT alternates between intense bursts of activity and fixed periods of less-intense activity or rest.

questions.question: What is the primary function of protein in the body?
questions.explanation: Protein is essential for building and repairing tissues, including muscles, bones, and skin.

questions.question: What is BMI?
questions.explanation: BMI is a measure that uses your height and weight to work out if your weight is healthy.
